Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Grant: DREAM STEM-Driving Research, Entrepreneurship, and Academics through Mastering STEM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Implementation project entitled - DREAM STEM-Driving Research, Entrepreneurship, and Academics through Mastering STEM - has the goal of contributing to greater participation of African Americans in the STEM workforce by providing the knowledge and skills for research and innovation. The objectives are: to increase science, technology, enginnering and mathematics (STEM) enrollment, particularly in Chemistry, Environmental, Earth, and Geospatial Sciences, Mathematics, and Physics programs; to increase retention in all STEM degree programs; to improve persistence in and increase the number of graduates from all STEM degree programs; to stimulate faculty research and innovations in STEM teaching and learning; and to enhance scientific education and technical training for STEM students. The objectives will be achieved through three primary project components: 1) Entrepreneurship in science education; 2) Development of students' identity as scientists; and 3) Faculty development through teaching and learning research innovation mini-grants. The project will include a Research, Discovery and Innovation Summer Institute to engage students in the science and engineering research and development portion of the entrepreneurship cycle, which can result in product and process innovations. By means of an extracurricular activity through a highly integrated science-based entrepreneurship program at North Carolina Central University students will earn a certificate in technological entrepreneurship when they graduate with a BS degree in a STEM discipline.

The information and knowledge expected to be obtained from the project will be determinants of whether students who developed entrepreneurial thinking and got entrepreneurial training will enroll in, be retained in, and persist in STEM degree programs at a higher rate; whether activities that facilitate science identity will retain students in STEM degree programs at a higher rate and improve their persistence to a STEM degree; and whether competitive mini-grants for faculty development will lead to innovations in STEM teaching and learning. Knowledge and lessons learned from the project will be disseminated to a wider audience through presentations at national meetings and publications in peer-review journals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
North Carolina Central University (NCCU) was awarded an Implementation Project Grant from the Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) of the National Science Foundation in 2012.  The project entitled “DREAM STEM—Driving Research, Entrepreneurship, and Academics through Mastering STEM”, defined an innovative approach to attracting, retaining, and training students in STEM degree programs at NCCU. The key objectives of the DREAM STEM Project were: (a) to increase, enrollment, retention, persistence, and graduation in STEM programs, specifically for underrepresented minority students; (b) to stimulate faculty research and innovations in STEM teaching and learning; and (c) to enhance scientific education and technical training of STEM students.

Intellectual Merit:

Unique to the DREAM STEM Project were three core components: 1) Entrepreneurship in science education; 2) Development of students’ identity as scientists; and 3) Faculty development through teaching and learning research innovation mini-grants.

The entrepreneurship in science education component in the DREAM STEM Project served as a strategy to attract students and hold their interest and academic pursuit of STEM through entrepreneurial thinking and training, where students see relevance and perceive benefit in doing science. The DREAM STEM Project developed and delivered Research, Discovery and Innovation (RDI) Summer Institute in which students engaged in guided research & development activities to innovate, complemented with entrepreneurial thinking training on how to carry out the market analysis and identify various sources of finance that they would use to fund their product. RDI students presented a business pitch and demonstration of the product prototype they created at an end of summer closing ceremony.

Student’s science identity development has been conceptualized as consisting of three overlapping elements: performance, competence, and recognition. The DREAM STEM Project accentuates students’ science identity through scholarships (Performance), undergraduate research experiences (Competence), and opportunities to attend and present at national STEM meetings (Recognition). Scholarship awards were performance-based tied to the student’s academic grades, as a motivational strategy to sustain high quality student outcomes. Successful undergraduate research experiences and internships help reinforce students’ identification with science and enhance student’s confidence to overcome the barriers that may detract from their initial STEM interests The DREAM STEM Project funded students to participate in summer undergraduate research experiences on- and off-campus, and internships with local industries in Research Triangle Park, North Carolina.  DREAM STEM undergraduate researchers and interns prepare and submit abstracts of their work to national conferences, and the DREAM STEM Project support students’ travel to attend and/or present oral and poster presentations at national conferences. At least 10 students participating or affiliated wit DREAM STEM have won awards and honors for their presentations at national meetings.

The DREAM STEM Project a competitive mini-grants program with external peer review and internal evaluation rubrics to facilitate faculty development in the area teaching-as-research. Faculty proposed research studies on the implementation of promising pedagogical strategies that have been should to work elsewhere, but not in a historically black college/university (HBCU). Two min-grants were awarded to faculty who implemented and tested strategies including course-based research experiences in chemistry and active engagement through interactive physics demonstrations. In each case, results indicated that students achieved higher course subject retention and increased confidence in doing science whether with classroom demonstrations or in classroom laboratory settings.  One book chapter and one journal article have been published on the works from the DREAM STEM Project. In addition, one manuscript has been submitted to a journal and a second manuscript is being drafted.

Outcomes of the DREAM STEM Project include higher enrollment; higher retention, persistence and graduation rates; significant positive mindset change in entrepreneurial thinking for students; and positive gains in students’ identity as scientists as observed by significant increase in their science performance and competence. Overall STEM enrollment was 8.6%, however enrollment in Physics increased by 82% now with over 40 majors when the program formerly was considered low-producing. DREAM STEM participants were retained at a rate of 97% after the first year compared to 57% for non-DREAM STEM students. Persistence rates of DREAM STEM participants was 90% compared to 30% for non-DREAM STEM. Four- and five-year graduation rates for DREAM STEM participants was 41% and 80% respectively; compared to 11% and 20% for non-DREAM STEM.

Broader Impacts:

The DREAM STEM Project funded 72 unduplicated participants in activities that included DREAM STEM Scholarships (41), Research Discovery Innovation Summer Institute (35), undergraduate research experiences and internships (50), summer bridge program (19), summer school tuition (37), book awards (69), conference travel (47), and work stipends (39).  During the grant period, thirty-two (32) DREAM STEM participants completed STEM degrees with, 38% Physics, 25% Biology, 19% mathematics, and 13% Chemistry. The demographics of the DTEM STEM graduates were: 72% African American, 4% White, 6% Hispanic, 3% Asian, and 6% two or more races; 53% male and 47% female.
